org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang

Class RolesConferredPrivilegesTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseTestCase
          • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseJDBCTestCase
            • org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.RolesConferredPrivilegesTest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public class RolesConferredPrivilegesTest
extends BaseJDBCTestCase
    This tests that SQL roles actually confer the correct privileges, that is, when privileges are granted to one or more roles and those roles are granted to other roles, to one or more users or to PUBLIC, sessions can make use of them correctly.

      • atestConferredPrivileges

        public void atestConferredPrivileges()

        Throws:

      • testViewInvalidation

        public void testViewInvalidation()
                          throws java.sql.SQLException
        When a view, a trigger or a constraint requires a privilege by way of the current role (or by way of a role inherited by the current role) at creation time (SELECT, TRIGGER or REFERENCES privilege respectively), a dependency is also registered against the current role. Whenever that role (it need no longer be current) - or indeed one of its inherited roles - is revoked (from the current user or from a role in the closure of the original current role) or dropped, the dependent view, trigger or constraint is potentially invalidated (the single dependency is against the original current role, not against the potentially n-ary set of roles in the closure of the current role used to find the required privileges). Due to DERBY-1632, currently the objects are dropped instead of being potentially revalidated. These tests check that invalidation actually happens and leads to a dropping of the dependent view (there are also no revalidation possibilities in play here, so even when DERBY-1632 is fixed these tests should work).
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • testTriggerInvalidation

      • testMinimumSelectPrivilege

        public void testMinimumSelectPrivilege()
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
        DERBY-4191 There are times when no column is selected from a table in the from list. At such a time, we should make sure that we make sure there is atleast some kind of select privilege available on that table for the query to succeed. eg of such queries select count(*) from t1 select count(1) from t1 select 1 from t1 select t1.c1 from t1, t2 In addition, the subquery inside of a NON-select query should require select privilege on the tables involved in the subquery eg update dbo.t set a = ( select max(a1) + 2 from dbo.t1 ) update dbo.t set a = ( select max(b1) + 2 from dbo.t2 ) For both the queries above, in addition to update privilege requirement on dbo.t(a), we need to require select privileges on columns/tables within the select list. So for first query, the user should have select privilege on dbo.t1 or dbo.t1(a1). Similarly, for 2nd query, the user should have select privilege on dbo.t2 or dbo.t2(b1)
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • testPSInvalidation

        Throws:

        schema - the schema to check
        table - the table to check
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - throws all exceptions

                                        java.lang.String[] columns,
